pullRequest.body:
This eliminates `(fun a ‚Ü¶ Œ≤) Œ±` in the type when applying a `FunLike`.


---

> I have an idea, let me see how far I get...

Answer: not far enough. `expandCoe` does a `headBeta` on the expression, which means that this shortcut instance does work but any tricks inside the original instance's type does not. So the way to go is indeed either a change in Lean core or to have this shortcut instance.
What would the change to Lean core look like?

> What would the change to Lean core look like?

I think we'd need to modify [`expandCoe`](https://github.com/leanprover/lean4/blob/6c5f79c0df01e9cd74ac4ee411ec392a5ac1b5d3/src/Lean/Meta/Coe.lean#L32) to do more aggressive `Œ≤` reduction. (But I haven't tried out if that indeed works.)

Following discussion on [Zulip](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/144837-PR-reviews/topic/.237905.20instance.20for.20non-dependent.20.60FunLike.60) and testing in #8185, you should delete the new instance and replace `FunLike.hasCoeToFun` with 
```lean 
instance (priority := 100) hasCoeToFun : CoeFun F (fun _ ‚Ü¶ ‚àÄ a : Œ±, Œ≤ a) where
  coe := @FunLike.coe _ _ Œ≤ _ -- need to make explicit to beta reduce for non-dependent functions
```
this will expose the function signature to beta reduction and yield the same benefits without the duplicate instance.

@negiizhao Please let us know your thoughts on this PR. Your insight on the performance impact from the extra beta expansion, your identification of a viable fix, and the hard work in making Mathlib build are the vast majority of the work here. 

Given the benefits, it would be nice to get this merged asap. üôè
What is the difference between the files in this PR and #8185? Can we close this one in favor of #8185?

Great! üòä Can you adjust the title and body of the PR and quickly compare to the fixes in #8185 to make sure things are as minimal as possible before merging? Thanks!

bors delegate+

:v: negiizhao can now approve this pull request. To approve and merge a pull request, simply reply with `bors r+`. More detailed instructions are available [here](https://bors.tech/documentation/getting-started/#reviewing-pull-requests).

I'm happy with this now, thanks! I'd like to jump into an editor once the cache is ready and fiddle with a couple proofs; please ping me if this PR is green and I haven't already done so. If I don't respond, I'm fine with it being merged in 8 hours.
bors merge

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Check all files imported](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/6883093857/job/18722934735)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/6883093857/job/18722935152)
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/6883093857/job/18722935388)

I'm impressed by the results, but I must say I'm not convinced that this is the way to go with respect to readability/ease of use. I count 46 files with code improvements and 40 files with code regressions (such as `rw` becoming `erw`, extra arguments needing to be specified, etc.). To have to make a manual choice between the two `hasCoeToFun` and `ndHasCoeToFun` instances seems likely to cause confusion.

Ideally we'd assign `hasCoeToFun` a type that beta-reduces more eagerly so there is no duplication at all. I have an idea, let me see how far I get...
Can you add a file in `test/` that demonstrates that the inferred type of non-dependent funlikes is improved?

I'm impressed by the results, but I must say I'm not convinced that this is the way to go with respect to readability/ease of use. I count 46 files with code improvements and 40 files with code regressions (such as `rw` becoming `erw`, extra arguments needing to be specified, etc.). To have to make a manual choice between the two `hasCoeToFun` and `ndHasCoeToFun` instances seems likely to cause confusion.

Ideally we'd assign `hasCoeToFun` a type that beta-reduces more eagerly so there is no duplication at all. I have an idea, let me see how far I get...

```suggestion
/-- A version of FunLike.hasCoeToFun for non-dependent functions, which gives a performance boost, and avoids unwanted missing beta-reduction. -/
instance (priority := 110) hasCoeToFunNonDependent : CoeFun F fun _ ‚Ü¶ Œ± ‚Üí Œ≤ where coe := FunLike.coe
```

Did any files end up needing this?
```suggestion
`attribute [local instance high] FunLike.hasCoeToFun` for better performance when you are using lots of dependent `FunLike` typeclasses.
```
to make it clear that this is only a performance concern.
I added it in `Mathlib.Geometry.Manifold.VectorBundle.SmoothSection`. It was the file that slowed down significantly in the first benchmark.
Note it down there too, I think

```suggestion
/-- Non-Dependent variant of `FunLike.hasCoeToFun`.

We give this higher priority because it is simpler and therefore significantly speeds up usages of `FunLike`. -/
instance (priority := 110) ndHasCoeToFun : CoeFun F fun _ ‚Ü¶ Œ± ‚Üí Œ≤ where coe := FunLike.coe
```
I think our comments crossed, https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/7905#discussion_r1372940923
Could you explain in the comment why the dependent version isn't just a fallback for the non-dependent version? (I assume it's because of `outParam`s.)
I think this should really just be giving performance advice, https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/7905#discussion_r1372943100

Small terminology fix:
```suggestion
Lean will try to synthesize non-dependent `FunLike` instances first by default. Use the command
`attribute [local instance high] FunLike.hasCoeToFun` if you want dependent `FunLike` instances
```
This one is rather worrying
Why did this go?
The `synTaut` linter reports it's a syntactic tautology.

Then there is a coercion missing; the statement should really be `FunLike.coe (f ‚Ä¢ g) = f ‚Ä¢ FunLike.coe g`, though written with `\u` isntead of `FunLike.coe` to allow your nondependent instance to fire.
Why was this de-`simp`ed? Does the same comment apply as elsewhere about `simpNF` getting confused?
Is a lemma with proof parameters that do not appear directly on the LHS (but in LHS there's a proof that uses it) appropriate as a `simp` lemma? If it should be, then I'll add a note.
Yes, I think this is still fine as a simp lemma, since `simp` creates `x ‚§≥ y` as a side-goal. Did the linter complain?
Yes, `simpNF` linter complains. I think this is because `x ‚§≥ y` doesn't appear directly on the LHS.
Is `x ‚§≥ y` a proof as you said it was, or is it data?
It's a proof https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Topology/Inseparable.html#Specializes
I preferred the original statement of this lemma.
(due to equalities of types being evil)

Let's be explicit here:
```suggestion
theorem coe_pointwise_smul [Semiring Œ≤] (f : Œ± ‚Üí Œ≤) (g : Œ± ‚Üí‚ÇÄ Œ≤) : ‚áë(f ‚Ä¢ g) = f ‚Ä¢ ‚áëg :=
```

I think we should get rid of this, since type equalities are evil. Does the proof below break without it?

(if not, then it doesn't belong in this PR anyway)
For the same reason as above, the version with `h : n = m` is no longer a simp lemma. But removing it won't break things.
I think all of the removed `simp` attributes should come with a comment referring to 7905; as far as I can tell, all of them look a bit iffy.

This looks like a bug to me, https://github.com/leanprover/std4/issues/365.

I suggest you replace all of these with `simpNF`, and add a comment referencing `std4#365`.
I've gone ahead and done that
This one looks a bit worrying
It's not necessary now (I can just revert it if necessary), but this will be faster.
I think best to revert anything that isn't direct fallout of this change. Any other cleanups can go in a separate PR if you think they're still a good idea
This one is a bit weird; I'll take a look once a cache is ready.
Was this rejected by `simpNF`? If so, in favor of what lemma?
`‚ü®x, ‚ü®h, rfl‚ü©‚ü© : f x ‚àà f '' s` is a proof.
That's not supposed to matter... Either way, I'm happy with the comments for now, this PR is clearly a big improvement in general.

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - perf(FunLike.Basic): beta reduce `CoeFun.coe`

```diff
+ ~Mathlib.CategoryTheory.Monoidal.Internal.Module             instructions        -6.8%
+ ~Mathlib.Combinatorics.HalesJewett                           instructions       -83.1%
+ ~Mathlib.FieldTheory.AbelRuffini                             instructions        -6.1%
```

```diff
+ ~Mathlib.Geometry.RingedSpace.PresheafedSpace.Gluing         instructions        -3.4%
+ ~Mathlib.GroupTheory.HNNExtension                            instructions        -7.0%
+ ~Mathlib.LinearAlgebra.CliffordAlgebra.Contraction           instructions        -8.2%
+ ~Mathlib.LinearAlgebra.CliffordAlgebra.Even                  instructions       -13.6%
+ ~Mathlib.LinearAlgebra.DFinsupp                              instructions       -12.3%
+ ~Mathlib.LinearAlgebra.Dual                                  instructions        -4.0%
+ ~Mathlib.LinearAlgebra.FreeModule.PID                        instructions       -50.9%
+ ~Mathlib.LinearAlgebra.Multilinear.Basic                     instructions        -9.9%
+ ~Mathlib.MeasureTheory.Integral.SetToL1                      instructions        -4.9%
+ ~Mathlib.NumberTheory.NumberField.Units                      instructions        -3.6%
+ ~Mathlib.RepresentationTheory.Character                      instructions       -28.9%
+ ~Mathlib.RepresentationTheory.GroupCohomology.Resolution     instructions       -56.0%
+ ~Mathlib.RingTheory.DedekindDomain.AdicValuation             instructions       -24.2%
+ ~Mathlib.RingTheory.IsTensorProduct                          instructions        -9.3%
+ ~Mathlib.RingTheory.Kaehler                                  instructions        -2.9%
+ ~Mathlib.RingTheory.PowerSeries.Basic                        instructions       -12.4%
+ ~Mathlib.RingTheory.RootsOfUnity.Basic                       instructions        -6.1%
+ ~Mathlib.RingTheory.Trace                                    instructions        -6.5%
```
Can you add a file in `test/` that demonstrates that the inferred type of non-dependent funlikes is improved?

I'm impressed by the results, but I must say I'm not convinced that this is the way to go with respect to readability/ease of use. I count 46 files with code improvements and 40 files with code regressions (such as `rw` becoming `erw`, extra arguments needing to be specified, etc.). To have to make a manual choice between the two `hasCoeToFun` and `ndHasCoeToFun` instances seems likely to cause confusion.

Ideally we'd assign `hasCoeToFun` a type that beta-reduces more eagerly so there is no duplication at all. I have an idea, let me see how far I get...

> I have an idea, let me see how far I get...

Answer: not far enough. `expandCoe` does a `headBeta` on the expression, which means that this shortcut instance does work but any tricks inside the original instance's type does not. So the way to go is indeed either a change in Lean core or to have this shortcut instance.
What would the change to Lean core look like?

> What would the change to Lean core look like?

I think we'd need to modify [`expandCoe`](https://github.com/leanprover/lean4/blob/6c5f79c0df01e9cd74ac4ee411ec392a5ac1b5d3/src/Lean/Meta/Coe.lean#L32) to do more aggressive `Œ≤` reduction. (But I haven't tried out if that indeed works.)

Following discussion on [Zulip](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/144837-PR-reviews/topic/.237905.20instance.20for.20non-dependent.20.60FunLike.60) and testing in #8185, you should delete the new instance and replace `FunLike.hasCoeToFun` with 
```lean 
instance (priority := 100) hasCoeToFun : CoeFun F (fun _ ‚Ü¶ ‚àÄ a : Œ±, Œ≤ a) where
  coe := @FunLike.coe _ _ Œ≤ _ -- need to make explicit to beta reduce for non-dependent functions
```
this will expose the function signature to beta reduction and yield the same benefits without the duplicate instance.

source.title: perf: try to speed up ideal quotient =?= submodule quotient

nodes.body:
@negiizhao Please let us know your thoughts on this PR. Your insight on the performance impact from the extra beta expansion, your identification of a viable fix, and the hard work in making Mathlib build are the vast majority of the work here. 

Given the benefits, it would be nice to get this merged asap. üôè
What is the difference between the files in this PR and #8185? Can we close this one in favor of #8185?

source.title: [Merged by Bors] - fix(Mathlib/Algebra/Lie/DirectSum): remove unused `R` argument from lemmas

nodes.body:
Great! üòä Can you adjust the title and body of the PR and quickly compare to the fixes in #8185 to make sure things are as minimal as possible before merging? Thanks!

I'm happy with this now, thanks! I'd like to jump into an editor once the cache is ready and fiddle with a couple proofs; please ping me if this PR is green and I haven't already done so. If I don't respond, I'm fine with it being merged in 8 hours.
